results.title: Color categorising behaviour of rhesus monkeys
results.brief_description: This psychological study is part of a research project on brain disorders. For over a year, adult male and female Rhesus monkeys and a baby monkey were trained and taught to sort various objects according to their size, color and shape. Such experiments and their results are of primary interest to psychology students.
results.description: This psychological study is part of a research project on brain disorders. results.title: Color and pigment in art
results.brief_description: Demonstrates by use of a glass prism that white light is actually a combination of several colors, which can be reproduced by pigments. Shows how the three primary colors can be mixed to make secondary colors and, in turn, intermediate colors. A color solid shows the three dimensions of color - hue, value and intensity, and examples illustrate how combinations of colors can create pleasing effects and different moods and feelings.

results.title: Color (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art in Action”.
Illustrates color in nature - in pigments, yarn, clay, wood, and other art materials in order to stimulate interest in experimentation and encourage children to put colors together in their own way.

results.title: The Colour of life
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film probes the perennial miracle of the growth of a seedling, the seasonal upsurge of life in a forest giant, and the mysterious alchemy of a single leaf. Presented in magnified dimension through time-lapse photography and animated diagrams, a maple leaf and segments of a tree serve to illustrate the physiological processes that go on in all plants.

results.title: The Colonies look ahead
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
A film survey of economic development, education and race relations in various British colonial territories. Progress in representative colonies, such as Kenya, is assessed on the basis of their ability to manage their own affairs and to achieve self-government. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.

results.title: Colonial children
results.brief_description: Re-enacts the home life and self-sufficiency of a family in colonial New England in the late 17th century. Shows the children learning lessons at home, and shows the duties and chores of each member of the family. Emphasises the role of religion in the home.

results.title: The Colonial chair
results.brief_description: Two men are each determined to purchase a colonial chair on sale at Sydney’s Salvation Army’s Collection and Waste Products Depot. After a short argument the victor carries off the chair on his motorbike. Filmed on several Saturday mornings, we see bargain hunters assembled outside the gates until 7.30 a.m. opening time. As the gates open there is a rush for the choicest lots in stoves, refrigerators, furniture and bric-a-brac. Photography: Ron Lowe

results.title: Colombo Plan and you
results.creator_credit: Department of Foreign Affairs and National Economic Council
results.brief_description: Tells something of the work being done by the Colombo Plan and of the assistance being given, by Australia amongst other nations, by means of the donation of machinery and the provision of technical advise. Focuses on the Philippines which is both a donor and a recipient of Colombo Plan and other forms of technical and economic assistance.

results.title: The Colombo Plan
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: A cartoon film on the Colombo Plan which links a number of countries throughout the world pledged to improve each other’s economic conditions. To increase prosperity and make the earth fruitful, technical knowledge and experience, equipment and funds, are essential before progress can be made. This cartoon shows how, in the past ten years, the people of Colombo Plan countries are benefitting from co-operation.

results.title: Colombia and Venezuela
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: Four sub-regions are determined by the topography of these two South American countries; the climate, the industries, and the population of these are studied - farming, shipping, mining and agriculture - with stress on the contrast between cities and countryside. The different types of people and their work, and the world trading economy of these countries are simply represented with the aid of animation.
